content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clear and precise statement, with a balanced, engaging response, quick and enjoyable to complete.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Simple and fun :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is a very fun and easy programming question, so it seems perfectly fine for clash of code.

A test case and its validator should be similar in structure. In your clash, this means:

• They should both have a similar number of inputs (N).

• The range of numbers (how small or large they are) should also be similar.

Currently:

• Test 3 and Test 4 use mostly 2-digit numbers.

• Validator 3 and Validator 4 use very large numbers (up to 9 digits).

• There are very few 3-digit and 4-digit integers in the inputs.

So:

* Please revise Test 3 and Validator 3 to use integers with 1 to 3 digits only.

* Please revise Test 4 and Validator 4 to use integers with 1 to 4 digits only.

Hope this clarifies.

-----

Also, please move this line from the Input section to the Constraints section:
It is guaranteed that there will be exactly one person left without a partner.

Thanks.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
I think "represented by" would be clearer than "presented in"

Great Problem and clear description.

But I have a suggestion, use 'unique' instead of 'odd'.
It is probably more precisely.

Looks like fun! Minor suggestions:

1. don't use "man" or "his" (in the Goal and Output sections). Instead use "person" or "their" respectively. This is more correct English.

2. In Constraints, use "999" instead of "10^3-1" for clarity.

Nice work and clear description.

When testing, the first 4 tests passed immediately even with a completely broken solution as the odd hobby is always the last item in the list after sorting. I would recommend to not use the maximum hobby value in some of the first test cases.

I recommend to clarify the output description with:
"One integer, the hobby of the single poor man".

Everything else seems clear to me.

Input section
* Please add "space-separated" in front of "integers".

Constraints section
* Please write one constraint per line.

* Please mention that in each case it's guaranteed to have a unique solution (if you've checked that's indeed the case.) 

Reason: Even an odd number of people doesn't guarantee such a situation, e.g. there is no unique solution for input of "1 2 3 4 5".

Cases
* Please revise the cases so that each pair of test and validator is similar in terms of BOTH the number of integers AND the magnitude of the output. (Currently only validators feature output of "big" numbers.)

Thanks.
Thanks for your suggestions. I have made changes to the statements based on your description. Please tell me if there are further modifies required.

Thank you for making the changes. Further modificiations required:

Input section
* Please move the last line to Constraints section.

Cases
* Test 3 isn't similar to Validator 3 yet.

* Test 4 isn't similar to Validator 4 yet.

* Please EITHER swap Test 5 with Validator 5 OR swap Test 6 with Validator 6, so that one of the "greater number" cases is a test and hence visible to a clash player.

Thanks again.

I modified the statement again, but I don't really know how to deal with the cases.
How should the test and the validator "similar"? Do they have to have the same data range, count or something else?

Thank you for your questions.

As I mentioned in one of my earlier comments, similarity is in terms of "BOTH the number of integers AND the magnitude of the output".

Also, please move "The given input data is guaranteed to have one and only one solution." to Constraints section.

Thanks.
